perturbation.original_text:
6.3. Termination for Breach.

(a) By Licensor. Licensor may terminate this Agreement at any time in the event that the Licensee is in material default or breach of any provision of this Agreement, and, if such default or breach is capable of cure, such default or breach continues uncured for a period of thirty (30) days after receipt of written notice thereof; provided, however, that in the event that the Licensee has in good faith commenced cure within such thirty (30) day period, but cannot practically complete such cure within such thirty (30) day period, the Parties shall negotiate a reasonable additional time to cure.
perturbation.changed_text:
6.3. Termination for Breach.

(a) By Licensor. Licensor may terminate this Agreement at any time in the event that the Licensee is in material default or breach of any provision of this Agreement, and, if such default or breach is capable of cure, such default or breach continues uncured for a period of fifteen (15) days after receipt of written notice thereof; provided, however, that in the event that the Licensee has in good faith commenced cure within such fifteen (15) day period, but cannot practically complete such cure within such fifteen (15) day period, the Parties shall negotiate a reasonable additional time to cure.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces an in-text contradiction by modifying the cure period for a breach from thirty (30) days to fifteen (15) days. This contradicts the licensee's ability to rectify a breach, creating ambiguity regarding the actual cure period allowed.

perturbation.original_text:
6.6. Effect of Termination.

(a) Upon termination (but not expiration) of this Agreement for any reason, Licensee shall be entitled to use the Licensed Domain Names and Licensed Content for a limited period of time, not to exceed ninety (90) days, during which it shall diligently work to transition to another solution. Upon expiration of this Agreement or such 90-day period, (i) all rights granted to Licensee under this Agreement with respect to the Licensed Domain Names and Licensed Content shall immediately cease, and (ii) Licensee shall immediately discontinue all use of the Licensed Domain Names and Licensed Content.
perturbation.changed_text:
6.6. Effect of Termination.

(a) Upon termination (but not expiration) of this Agreement for any reason, Licensee shall be entitled to use the Licensed Domain Names and Licensed Content for a limited period of time, not to exceed thirty (30) days, during which it shall diligently work to transition to another solution. Upon expiration of this Agreement or such 90-day period, (i) all rights granted to Licensee under this Agreement with respect to the Licensed Domain Names and Licensed Content shall immediately cease, and (ii) Licensee shall immediately discontinue all use of the Licensed Domain Names and Licensed Content.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces an in-text contradiction by stating licensee shall be entitled to use the Licensed Domain Names and Licensed Content for a limited period of time not to exceed thirty (30) days after the termination of this agreement, while also stating "Upon expiration of this Agreement or such 90-day period". This contradicts the transition period for the Licensed Domain Names and Licensed Content, creating ambiguity regarding the duration of the transition period for licensee.

perturbation.original_text: 10.1. Taxes. Each Party shall be responsible for taxes that should be borne by it in accordance with applicable Law. If any Party pays any taxes that should have been borne by the other Party in accordance with Law, such other Party shall reimburse such Party within seven (7) days after its receipt of documentation evidencing such tax payment so incurred by such Party.
perturbation.changed_text: 10.1. Taxes. Each Party shall be responsible for taxes that should be borne by it in accordance with applicable Law. If any Party pays any taxes that should have been borne by the other Party in accordance with Law, such other Party shall reimburse such Party within thirty (30) days after its receipt of documentation evidencing such tax payment so incurred by such Party.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces an in-text contradiction by modifying the reimbursement period for taxes from seven (7) days to thirty (30) days. This creates ambiguity regarding the actual reimbursement period allowed.
